title: 112_hr851
content: The Act titled "Clean Energy Jobs Act of 2011" includes provisions for renewable fuels and fossil fuels. It extends incentives for biodiesel, renewable diesel, and alcohol used as fuel, as well as additional duties on ethanol. The Act includes provisions for renewable fuels such as biodiesel and renewable diesel incentives. It also addresses various tax credits related to oil and gas production, passive activity losses, and income from domestic production activities. Additionally, there are measures to increase revenues to reduce the federal budget deficit. SEC. 101 extends biodiesel and renewable diesel incentives until December 31, 2016. The effective date for the amendments is after December 31, 2011. SEC. 102 extends the income tax credit for alcohol used as fuel. SEC. 102 extends the income tax credit for alcohol used as fuel until December 31, 2016, with amendments taking effect upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 103 extends the excise tax credit for alcohol used as fuel until December 31, 2016, with amendments effective upon enactment. SEC. 104 extends additional duties on ethanol until January 1, 2017. TITLE II focuses on the amortization of geological and geophysical expenditures. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 changes the term "major integrated oil company" to "covered large oil company." A covered large oil company is defined as a taxpayer that is a major integrated oil company or has gross receipts exceeding $50,000,000 for the taxable year. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011, treating section 52 as one person and amending the heading for paragraph (5) of section 167(h) to include "and other large taxpayers." SEC. 202 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude non-small, independent oil and gas companies from certain tax benefits. It applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. SEC. 203 introduces an enhanced oil recovery credit, excluding non-small, independent oil and gas companies from certain tax benefits. It applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 205 amends subsection (c) of section 263 of the Internal Revenue Code to exclude non-small, independent oil and gas companies from certain tax benefits. This change applies to amounts paid or incurred in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 205 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude non-small, independent oil and gas companies from certain tax benefits. This change applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 206 addresses tertiary injectants. The amendment to Section 193 of the Internal Revenue Code excludes non-small, independent oil and gas companies from certain tax benefits, specifically related to qualified carbon dioxide disposed in secure geological storage. The amendment made by this section states that persons treated as a single employer shall be treated as 1 person. Effective Date: Expenses incurred after December 31, 2011. SEC. 207 amends section 469(c) of the Internal Revenue Code to exempt taxpayers who are not small, independent oil and gas companies from certain passive activity loss limitations. SEC. 208 relates to income attributable to domestic production activities. SEC. 208 amends Section 199 of the Internal Revenue Code to exclude income from oil and gas production for non-small, independent companies. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. SEC. 301 states that any increase in revenues from the amendments made by this Act will be used to reduce the Federal budget deficit or the Federal debt if there is no deficit for a fiscal year.
